and clearer for businesses, providing them with a unique and comprehensive response that will enable them to reconcile the goal of simplifying the obligations desired by all with the reality of the day-to-day life of small businesses that need them.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that is currently dividing both the European institutions and the business community, and to conduct an impact study.

Mr President, Commissioner and my dear colleagues, As my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and other colleagues have pointed out, on 27 and 28 February, the violent storm Cynthia hit several regions in France, causing 53 deaths and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity. It caused devastating floods on the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected
Three French departments were thus declared to be in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and the Pays de la Loire.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and resolutions, but also and above all through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.
I therefore call on the European Commission, and my colleague Christophe Bchus agrees with me, to quickly release the Union's Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civilian intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur Jrg Leichtfried for his report and his spirit of cooperation on this issue. I particularly support his proposals on the financing of aviation security, since we are talking here about aviation security and not air safety.
Our committee has been fighting for many years to have the principle accepted that stricter safety measures must be borne by the Member States. I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security is not just about travelers, but concerns all citizens. And it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers should be the only ones responsible for financing security measures at airports and on board aircraft.
This is especially true in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, where states finance security measures either partially or totally, as the case may be.
And I therefore think that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our transport committee.
Then I had another point to address quickly

While I support the progress in terms of non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of security charges.
While requiring compliance with common rules, Member States must be allowed to retain their current system of levying fees

And so, in states like Spain or Italy or France, fees are voted on by Parliament. And in this case, it must be the appeals authority against the laws that serves as the independent supervisory authority.
This is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner. The report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that agriculture has a place and a role to play in the fight against global warming.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and the climate.
But it still requires that men, and Europe in particular, take responsibility for combating what is called global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its fossil fuel consumption, and, above all, adopt a different behavior.
The side participated very actively in carbon fixation in order to globally combat fewer carbon emissions and more fixed and sequestered carbon.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move from an approach that is, how to put it, compartmentalized, which consists of opening a directive every time a problem arises,
on soil, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and to try to address the agricultural issue with the ambition to deal with it in a comprehensive, systemic way.

And in this approach, we must be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but at the same time actively participates in carbon sequestration.
This is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is close to my heart, also related to the soil, to the ability of European soils to fix organic carbon.

And I believe that this approach that I am opening up in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in Pnire in Brussels, this approach should enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, in order to ensure that it is capable of being economically efficient, ecologically efficient, and I also think that, from that moment on, it will be socially efficient.

So this report deals with a specific issue, the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it aims, I hope in any case, to open up other perspectives to fuel in particular the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
And I address the Commission, I will address, and I have done so often, the agricultural committees, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity,
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 CAP must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report and this is what I hope Parliament will follow, by a large majority.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over all other considerations. And under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and total reopening of airspace after just one or two test flights appears to be, at the very least, indecent.
Mr Hnin spoke earlier about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with trains. I would like to take this opportunity to express my regret at the air travel paralysis...
This has been exacerbated in some countries, such as France, by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our topic, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
It is a common-sense decision in a context already marked by crisis, but these aids must be exceptional in nature.

And in this regard, I hope that among the criteria chosen for the ROC 3 will be the exemplary conduct demonstrated by the airlines in compensating their customers who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that certain companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261-2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not have to bear the financial cost as well.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And that is not normal either.

Airlines and travel agencies have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we've been experiencing for the past few days, and therefore we must ensure that travelers are properly compensated for flights that have been canceled.
Thank you, Mr. President. The press has no shortage of words to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences: disorder, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly regarding the magnitude of the colossal, abyssal financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

And while I welcome the possibility of considering the allocation of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been strongly approved since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed about the European management of events.

Knowing that 750,000 European passengers have been affected, many of whom are still stranded all over the world. Knowing that the economic losses are exponential with the passage of time. How can we explain that it took not only...
not one, two, three or four, but five days for European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Two, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as a matter of top priority. But today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in areas

With a secure environment, unchanged weather conditions, and the volcano still active, one has to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided sooner, more quickly.

Three. A dynamic action model has been developed. The evolution according to the weather and the activity of the volcano can change from hour to hour. Who will continue to carry out the updated safety assessment of the corridors?
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this continues, worsens, or recurs, which is likely, the management model put in place will need to provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data, better

coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but we must also take into account the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers who also have a right to information and assistance.
Or, up to now, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like, in turn, after other speakers, to express my gratitude to our colleague Mends Divigo who has accomplished remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
The debates within the Committee on Conventional Affairs lasted a long time. They were equal to the challenge and equal to the intensity and interest that, of course, the
European parliamentarians are quite legitimately discussing the major issue that concerns them most: the composition of our assembly and the procedures for designating its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has managed to bring together sometimes differing opinions and contributions and synthesize, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the opinions and views.
I wanted to thank him for that.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both concerning the convening of the IGC and those concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are imbued with realism, pragmatism, and efficiency.
This is, I believe, what, overall, on other subjects as well, our fellow citizens expect from Europe.
Mr President, Mr Dali, Commissioner, it is with great strength that this draft report, as presented just now by Mr Pterl, takes up the lines
Director of Communication for the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to commend the work done by Mr. Pterl, the rapporteur, in drafting this report, and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat Group, I wanted to focus, among other things, on the following issues: first, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of better access to information.

containing carcinogenic chemicals and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union. And finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that could include people suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we have been considering while providing our support for this draft report.
Yes, thank you Madam President. The oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is a true ecological and economic disaster.
It would appear that irregularities have been found in the granting of forest permits by the US Department of the Interior.
This would be an unforgivable oversight, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When one considers that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states around the world, if these permits were granted with the same laxity, it would pose a truly serious problem for the entire world.
elected representatives from outermost European regions and OCTs composed entirely of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly 130.
In total, spread across the three continents, I must express here my great concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, which must set an example, reviews the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms with the utmost rigor.
Moreover, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms now fall under the jurisdiction of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international authority?

After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancn, the European Union would be honoured to initiate a genuine global governance framework for the research, protection and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
In continuity with the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the East and South of the Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report by Vincent Pion points out, we cannot overlook either the potential of this region or the dangers it poses.
However, having the lucidity to recognize this, since the bombing of Gaza and the continued colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
the political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learned in the coming hours or days that he is a daily drinker.
We must not give up, however. But the European Union must take greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States with the monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are crucial for our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr President, Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food safety situation has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans. And one in three consumers remains wary of product quality.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is a necessity for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
And then, I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We want a specific regulation for wine and spirits to be developed in the next three years, instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr President, Commissioner.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian ships by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we grant to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters, and therefore concerns the international community, and is of particular interest to Europe, which borders the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more and become more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we are showing is not enough
We must also express a political will and take the necessary steps to make ourselves heard.
The brutal action of the Israeli army against the Mavi Marmara has provoked emotion and condemnation.
Emotion over the nine civilian victims of the assault, condemnation because this boarding in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.
In doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its people because, in the end, we see the ultimate goal of security in the region moving further away with the strengthening of the extremes.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.

However, I would like to point out that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, as well as on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I hope that the government of Israel will agree that this investigation includes substantial international participation in order to finally find the paths of justice in this region. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it served only this purpose, would at least have the merit of highlighting how Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive comments on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the Union's demands are always emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner seem systematically undervalued or scorned, whether it is in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also notice that the firmness shown by most Member States and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, seems to be reserved exclusively for Russia.

The language is more police-like, diplomacy is more subdued, as if we are talking about China, for example, with its systematic violations of the rule of law, not to mention the Laogai camps, this global factory in terms of European minimum social requirements, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to remind you of the adage "Ad angusta per augusta" "To the heights, by the narrow paths" for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal poison of Marxism that for so many decades bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that still lie ahead.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European superstate itself fails to achieve any of its lofty goals despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but point out that this assembly showed more leniency towards the Soviet Union than towards Russia.

Moreover, it is often the same people who yesterday advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for Mr. Gorbachev's participation in the common home, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Union-Russia partnership.

In this regard, I must inform you, if you are not already aware, of new historical facts that will emerge as a result of the gradual translation of the secret Soviet archives that a brave Mr. Pavel Stroilov managed to obtain. These archives have already revealed much and will continue to do so.

The conventional wisdom about the end of the Cold War was a nasty surprise. In reality, Mr. Gorbachev, it was the perfidy of today's Euro-enthusiastic powers that were eager to make certain Soviet projects possible back then.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened for the benefit of all parties.

This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interest, and common risk than certain states that you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, one thing is clear - I say, it has become an inescapable necessity: to innovate, to be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will eventually be a giant leap, leading us towards true economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we achieve a genuine fiscal federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves have decided on it?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which I am nonetheless pleased about.
Strengthening the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact is a good thing, but there can be no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who violate it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified. This is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with the decisions made, such as the famous competitiveness evaluation dashboard, because that is what it is about: getting back to competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
It also commends the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, and the acceleration of financial regulatory reform.
Mr President of the Council, all these decisions and guidelines seemed unrealistic, illusory, and even truly hypothetical a few months, or even a few weeks ago.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound cultural change on the scale of European small steps policy.
But having said that, it is now imperative that in October, the states implement these guidelines in a very concrete manner.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or simply a pious hope, something that we will all bitterly regret and that a majority of citizens will have to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and it is clear that Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss it because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we are asking to postpone the debate and the vote on the Gallo report, that is to say, until September, September 2, when we will have to see what the Conference of Presidents decides.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to ripen and discuss it in September.

Thank you, Madam President. I must admit that I find it difficult to keep up with my colleagues who love to flex their muscles and claim a monopoly on our legitimacy vis--vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a reasoned position,
we are defending what appears to be a general European interest in the face of rigid states, the situation is completely changing.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament has played this role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am my group's shadow rapporteur, I have, like the rapporteur Mrs Goulard, advocated an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms that ensure a certain level of efficiency and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this group and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I will withhold the names of all the institutions and all those great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
we can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow that macro-prudential supervision is backed by a strong Community institution, while micro-prudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
We have forgotten ourselves so much, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start on a sound basis, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The final agreement reached on the revision of the directives on industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.

This final package incorporates the key points of the position I defended with several of my colleagues on the Environment Committee, which aimed to make this text an ambitious yet realistic piece of legislation.
First, maintaining a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to commend the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and is now limited to certain sectors, making it seem much more feasible.

It is also important to note that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOX quotas.
A few caveats not to be forgotten, however, and more particularly the provisions concerning the ground.
Since the SOL directive is still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by the Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A tremendous amount of work has been done from all sides to avoid sending this text back to conciliation, a text that, I must remind you, is of crucial importance both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings a new set of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let's not forget that other disasters of this kind are taking place elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular about what is happening today, as well as what has been happening for a long time in Nigeria.
That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules for the management of platforms, not only European rules, but also international rules.
as far as the European Union is concerned, I believe it is necessary for it to equip itself preventively to combat this disaster, and I believe it is obvious
and that all of this argues, as Mrs. Damanaki said, for a firm and decisive choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
and the European Union should set an example in this regard.

Mr President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur at a time when the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tons of beef.
A new opening of our market will be made at the expense of breeders from disadvantaged European areas without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
we cannot accept it.
Europe buys 38 million tons of soybeans and cattle feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies, Cargill, ADM, Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for cattle feed.
Environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be rendered futile by this draft bilateral agreement
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and its farmers in order to obtain random counter-services for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the farming families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced of this, one need only read the report by the Tyson group. An American company, a heavyweight in the international meat market.
which announces that it has invested in Brazil in order, I quote, and this is in its report, "to use this country as an export platform for Europe".
Other companies, such as Doux, had already anticipated this approach by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had suffered as a result of this operation.
Europe, without wanting to pursue its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks
against the peasants. We must stop
Yes, Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that could result from the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, it is to be feared, and as a Member of Parliament for an outermost region, I have experience of banana agreements. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will impose a difficult cost on many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a concern that this agreement will further shift Mercosur agriculture towards a productivist model, to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.

A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially in the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Rowe.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would simply like to say that perhaps we have not done a good job with our agenda today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter the territory of Europe, products that do not respect our social or environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be for nothing.
To put it very clearly, we cannot continue to live in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental constraints, health traceability, and safety measures,
to our farmers on the grounds that consumers need to be protected, and on the other hand, allow products that can freely enter our continent without adhering to these standards.
The question that is being asked behind the negotiations with Mercosur is indeed that one.

And the way things were initiated, regardless of what we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that things took place in the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to have a positive appreciation of a negotiation that is taking place, while the negotiation at the WTO is continuing in parallel,
For the sake of consistency, consumer protection and the defence of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Thank you, Madam President. I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, Jos Bov, and the Commissioner, as well as Mr. Dess's speech before mine, regarding the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important that we keep in mind that in the debate we are having, we are dealing with a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices rise,
They are very quickly passed on to the distribution level. And when prices fall at the production level, there is no impact on consumers.
So there is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is called added value within the sector.

And I think that Jos Bov's report offers several perspectives that need to be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission, in order to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector.
what proposals are we making to ensure that producers are united, organized, and have more influence within the sector in order to negotiate?
That is the question you raised, Commissioner of Interprofessional Organizations, but it is also a question raised about the contractual basis that will be put in place.
And I argue, and it is in the report, that this contractual basis is a European framework.
We cannot let each country deal with this problem on its own.
There needs to be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposal, an inseparable line of thought for me.
Secondly, of course, there is the issue of price transparency.
And in this regard, I am in favor of setting up this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers about price trends.
So there you have it, I support the proposals that have been made and I hope, as Mr. Desse said, that there will be a majority to follow through.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to take this opportunity today to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and enhance its regional diversity.
In these times of negotiation for the new framework programmes 2014-2020, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated areas requires more than a set of derogating measures.
we need a horizontal approach
We must establish instruments capable of making all areas of community action coexist in synergy in order to enhance their added value.
Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new Union strategy for the ORs that the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I agree with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find that a bit flippant on the part of the Council, I must say that too.
As the next summit approaches on October 6, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely attempt to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year at this time, we were already busy in this very chamber urging Europe to do everything possible to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
we saw that the result did not live up to our hopes and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, if not even much more acute.

In order to be able to compel or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our determination is absolutely intact, showing for example that we are providing the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this reason, the implementation of innovative financing, and I heard President Sarkozy's speech at the UN yesterday, becomes a necessary necessity.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not doing enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat in the end. And a way to protect our jobs and our businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalue family leave is beyond dispute. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefit that is difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold. 1. The economic context, that's true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades. 2. The legal shortcomings of the report, because the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not compatible.
Let's take the adoption leave that is mentioned in the text in the same way as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to biological mothers.
I am actually the additional addendum that Mrs. Morin was talking about, added to the Estrella report.

If the goal is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the labor market, adoptive women who have become mothers on the same footing as others are entitled to the same rights and protections at work.
they are mothers like any other, fully entitled to adopt a child, whether it is more or less than 12 months old, so please no discrimination, as it is stated in the text
Regarding adoption, I regret that the text was not thoroughly enough explored.
It was not even supported by the Rambol impact study.
This is all rather poorly executed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs. Estrella's report, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their role as parents in a society that is

increasingly dismissive of the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their job or sacrificing their job for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council. I would like to speak and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded so far.

We discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints we are aware of, that is, those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These public deficits at the national level constrain the European deficit, where these deficits at the national level must give a new direction and a new impetus at the European level.
That is the question.
And I ask you, Commissioner, especially to try to think, when discussing a budget review, when we start talking about the budget outlook for the post-2013 period, not to...
remain totally absorbed by the context of the crisis. Unless we tell ourselves, and tell all the citizens of Europe, that Europe will definitely remain in crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and debt. But it is also about preparing for the exit from the crisis.
And this is where the budgetary question arises.

As Joseph Dehoede immediately pointed out, we will only be able to emerge from the crisis if the European budget, because it is European, is capable of providing us with the means to regain what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

That is the issue. And it is in this light that we must discuss the budget, rather than doing what we do all too often, which is constantly incorporating the issue of the crisis, the issue of deficits. And in this regard, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed anything with Mr. Van Rompuy, in order to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand with the Council today, while Parliament is asking for one thing, and in particular from the Commission, is to try to pull the European project forward. And this is happening through the budget.
So you've noted a number of things on which we fully agree.
More flexibility is needed.
Of course, we need to find a way to work together to achieve a much more flexible budget. Because it is a necessity, Europe's responsiveness is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on that. All agree. It is a necessity.
But what we need to be clear about is that we need a timetable. We need to set common goals, Commissioner. It can't just be words, commitments, and promises.

These texts are, incidentally, very interesting and I agree with them practically 100%. But now we need to get down to specifics. And in particular, we need to address a crucial issue that we keep circling around: own resources.

How do we ensure that we have our own resources for Europe tomorrow? Not for Europe, but for all European citizens. And to find together the path to growth and an even stronger path for Europe tomorrow.
It is up to you, Commissioner.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers about European economic governance, about the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges that our nations and the G20 members face, and which, in my opinion, must be addressed in the context of the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that on these two issues, which are real threats to global growth and which cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must...

manage to organize themselves, to establish common positions, to give themselves the means to speak with a single voice at the upcoming G20 summits in Seoul, and those that will follow, and more broadly on the world stage. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. My dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio for the quality of the report and for the ambitious proposal it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its rightful place in a debate that is crucial for the future of Europe, and we can only be encouraged by this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has revealed the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
So I take note of Mr. Feillot's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
To achieve this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of the states, which is not always popular,
It's restrictive, but we have no choice.

I believe that the report clearly demonstrates the stakes involved in the marine environment in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transportation, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In view of such a finding, it is up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it instead?
But it must be noted that the resolution does not go very far down this path.
One cannot claim to occupy a leadership position in global politics with 50 million euros.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, being present in all oceans, it would have been possible to make a change.
It was wise to give them a major role in a major ocean strategy, which unfortunately was not included in the report and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam, Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent Office.
In addition, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He believes that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
As the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it still raises great concerns and is far from being unanimously accepted.
I believe it would be useful for our American counterparts to provide a very clear answer to our fellow citizens. On two points, can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is the Acta in their eyes a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement from which China, India, and Brazil are already absent, and which is not implemented by the United States, would lose much of its credibility.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Throughout this difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but this truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory.
I would like to thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr Gauzs, who, after this particularly painful birth for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the issue of how to treat third countries must be considered in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
thanks in particular to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold in the European Union will indeed be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore more or less speak of a "level playing field",
However, during the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national investment regime, while EU funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It will then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world because they will be less flexible and more cult-like.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was partly inevitable,

As for the custodians, let us also note that we will make the exercise more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities they will have to assume. Their increased costs should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also involve difficulties that we must be aware of.

Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and to follow the prescribed treatment to the letter.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive submitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we see as nonsensical in terms of responding to patients' actual needs.
This operation is of no interest to either the citizens or the Member States,
Instead, it meant more bureaucracy, increased expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a proposal to reject these texts, thereby asking the Commission to revise its draft.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schilter from the Green group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I commend, to make significant revisions to the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to each individual's needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has placed greater emphasis on patients' rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.
In light of the compromise amendments achieved, we have decided to withdraw our motion to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has managed to counterbalance the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse to allow health professionals to be used as tools to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients without any control by health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant, and moreover, as I conclude, what happened with the Mediator medication shows just how vigilant we must be and ensure that this balance is maintained, as we have sought with this draft report.

Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Minister. Union and realism will be expressed, at least I hope so, during tomorrow's vote on our resolution regarding this 16th conference of the parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to achieve the pragmatic objectives that we will need to reach collectively, but also defend the sine qua non conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is inadequately protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for all that, squander our present and future knowledge, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same scale, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tool.
Finally, more controversially, and as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current Clean Development Mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, albeit with regret, that the real negotiating power does not lie with the European Parliament.
But the willingness of many MEPs, including myself, to work and participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have experienced in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, the same must apply to all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union often presents the economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Is she therefore despairing because these agreements are not being signed quickly enough?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Clearly, opinions differ on the quality of these agreements. And as long as these differing opinions persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategy, while Europe often only responds by opening up markets.
This is the kind of listening that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly must impose on itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow the same approach if we want to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets." And the goal is their outright departure from this region. A region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation that we have been passively observing for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation at the situation.
Discrimination, in any form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
My colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently taking place in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of the Constitutional Council of this country to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the EU-ACP Assembly, the Coas and soon, certainly, the European Parliament are demanding respect for the official proclamation
election results and the installation of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I would remind you, is a body validated by the UN.
All the political groups in the European Parliament have expressed their agreement on these essential points in a joint statement.

They also called for an end to any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, and which must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Thank you, Madam President. I, in turn, would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done an outstanding job and added significant value from the European Parliament to the texts initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizens' initiative that we in the EPP are preparing to vote for with enthusiasm is a major step forward in the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us make no mistake, this instrument can truly change the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
it can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.

it can help to foster a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women who are citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together, and who come together on truly European issues.
But let's not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to take the necessary enforcement measures quickly. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens, for this is about strengthening European democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like, in turn, like several of our colleagues, to address the issue of the persecution of Christians throughout the world, particularly Eastern Christians.
We do not need to recall the horrific acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to reiterate this point, as well as defend Christians in the East as everywhere else in the world, advocate for religious freedom, diversity of

it is advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, universal values, at least that is what we are all convinced of here.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to turn words into actions.
And so I urgently call on the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the Foreign Ministers,
take precise measures, to implement a precise, concrete action plan, to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
And allowing a lawless zone to establish itself on Europe's doorstep is a danger that we must fight against firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilians.
For my part, I deplore the loss of life and the taking of hostages and am concerned for the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking coming from the Sahel.
Or, nowadays, drug, arms, and human traffickers bypass Morocco by going through Mauritania towards the Canary Islands in the direction of the European Union.
It is the responsibility, it seems to me, of the European Union to take action to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
I join in the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been made towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all freedom fighters.
a thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been noted for its lack of reaction, must indeed stand by the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them successfully open their countries up to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in order to initiate a peaceful transition, prepare the organization of the upcoming elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity through development and social peace, an economy that will enable the youth to find employment.

In conclusion, I would say that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave of change across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.
But beware, faced with this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, as my colleagues have repeatedly pointed out,
At a time when Europe is considering a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot overlook the immense potential of intelligently valorizing our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection systems. Addressing problems of leakage or illegal export of said materials. Or even increasing our collection targets, but also must be at the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Empowering citizens is crucial. If we want to implement effective legislation,
And to achieve this, my dear Karl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but citizens cannot be absolved of responsibility for the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be active participants, not passive observers, in European environmental policy.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner. I would first like to share the comment that Mrs McGuinness just made about the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The issue that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that this can have for a number of populations around the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The trend of increasing prices for agricultural products and raw materials is a long-term trend, in my opinion, and will continue for three essential reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase in prices.

of the world's population. Second, the fact that we have entered a period of problematic climate variability due to global warming, whether it be drought or flooding. And third, because the world is also developing
As new emerging countries emerge, consumption levels are rising.
So the tension in agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility. And price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is this issue that we must also address if we want to resolve both the agricultural and food issues.

And to do this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, we need transparency on stocks. But we also need a public policy on stocks, both in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the UN level.

And secondly, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volumes to have no connection with the physical quantities that are traded on the markets.

We cannot accept that, on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this may have, since it is about the food of the world and humanity. And I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences. We need a strong European policy and we are strategically reaffirming Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.

And secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that on a global scale, and Europe is a player, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, As in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on global markets,
we are only at 3% of the 2008 level.
The decline in production in certain traditional exporting areas due to climate change, the diversion of grain to agrofuel production, and speculation
The financial policies that have exacerbated the upward effects are responsible for this situation, as shown by reports from the IMF, the French authorities, and as the Commission also states.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1.50 a day.
Since October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take similar measures to those voted on in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial funds in agricultural commodity markets.
This is the first step to counter the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European breeders.
they are no longer able to feed their animals
Hundreds of farms are going bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be wise today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must address the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
First, the creation of stocks in grain-producing countries to make them available to farmers at a subsidized price immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of meat prices paid to farmers to the evolution of the price of animal feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aid intended for cereal support to animal production. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a catch
The H1N1 flu episode of 2009-2010 showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As the shadow rapporteur on this issue, I believe it was necessary to make these observations, but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens, who, it must be said, and this is what seems to me to be most damaging, have probably lost some confidence in public health messages.

Mrs. Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities, which include, among other things, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between member states, better coordination with the
European health institutions, clarification of the roles of European health risk management structures, an evaluation of vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
It is therefore a good report, and I congratulate the rapporteur. However, it is obviously essential that it does not remain a dead letter.
This is the responsibility of our member states, which retain the majority of the relevant powers. It is therefore a genuine responsibility to be taken towards our citizens.
Thank you, Mr. President. It is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani Minister for Christian Religious Minorities, Mr. Bhatti.
This terrorist assassination follows many others of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis who love human rights and are defenders of human and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
And I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Mrs. Sherry Raymond.
And I also wanted, once again, with vigor, to ask all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations aimed at
prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, with a clause on respect for religious freedom and human rights. Thank you.
Mr President, for your information, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate bubble and credit, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
Ireland's public deficit and the cumulative budget balance of central, local and particularly social security administrations was estimated at 32% of GDP in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the Mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet obligations for change in the social and fiscal spheres, whereas these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a doctor, I would say that in the case of fever, it is useless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without trying to treat the cause.
If these funds are allocated, it is up to this state to clean up its finances in order to cover its excessive deficit and correct its previous mistakes.
This austerity plan is expected to improve the GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as an individual, a bank will not interfere in a person's private life and management, but will make a personal loan conditional on a guarantee of solvency. Similarly, the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

Thus, while respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the minimum legal wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which would, for example, dangerously impose a minimum European wage level, but a protection of the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is of course important to help Ireland, as well as other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, especially not at the price of having a state that is unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have said earlier, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
And each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
and 5 million of our fellow citizens were left stranded without any real alternative transport solution.
And a year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is indeed planned for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, ICAO, and IATA, but it is essential that EASA takes on real leadership for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.
This data, as we saw last April, can however be contradictory and can lead each member state to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace, motivated less by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of EASA is essential in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond informing VAC, EASA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders involved will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with EASA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the creation of the Single European Sky.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this text is important.
This is not a revolution. We cannot say that everything was bad before and everything is perfect now.
But nonetheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
In my opinion, the main issues relate to better regulation of distance selling, particularly on the Internet. And that's chapter 3. Because we need to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful. It broadens consumer choice, allows them to get the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans to find new markets.
To make progress in this area, it had to be done in a truly European way, that is, on a few very targeted points, implementing a complete harmonization of everyone's rights and duties.
In practical terms, an Italian customer buying from a Belgian or German site needed to know that they would now benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that the withdrawal period will be extended to 14 days throughout the Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without the fear of a nasty surprise later on.
This means that thanks to the double-click, he will correctly verify his order.
obviously all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes one cannot even find a trace of them in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one's habits a little in the service of the community and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text still needs to be improved, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur Andra Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the EU's internal market is very fragile.
this political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number 7, after the first paragraph, a first indent, ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the freedom of the individual.
freedom of speech and assembly and the right to demonstrate peacefully and to listen to and take into account the legitimate demands of demonstrators and ensure their safety.

Thank you, Madam President, my dear colleagues, Commissioner. The open skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only one step. A step that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the committee itself have pointed this out.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.
Let me draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer. Because the pilots I am part of are faced with a dilemma.
The European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so at the expense of 80,000 to 90,000 general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some holding only one American license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of the companies and jobs linked to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security basis.
there are 31 times fewer accidents among holders of American licenses.

The objectives of the basic regulatory text 216-2008 make it possible to provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, for which there is no point in waiting for hypothetical agreements that were postponed in 2014.

So, I propose a very open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I sometimes come to Parliament, flying myself to demonstrate to you that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or support certain things that have been said previously.
But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, which the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be solved by any single Member State alone.
No Member State should face the challenges it faces alone, and in my view, these challenges are faced by the entire European Union.
This is why I am calling for the European Union's ability to organize and respond in a common, united manner.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European immigration and asylum policy.
More than a year ago, a European pact on asylum and immigration was adopted.
The time has now come, I think, to put it into very concrete terms.
So we have of course listened to the Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations she made.
I wanted to revisit it and strongly endorse some of its proposals.
yes, we must strengthen Frontex's resources at all costs

It is necessary to strengthen the human resources, material resources, and financial resources of the Frontex agency, and to enable it to provide more substantial support for the Hermes and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for the Member States that are facing, I would say, in the first place, the increased migratory flows that we are experiencing today.
and this will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to establish closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, accompany them of course, help them, find instruments
The Commissioner was talking about mobility partnerships, I believe she went to Tunisia to discuss this.
And yes, we need to strengthen these instruments in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a precise and concrete spirit. Thank you.

Commissioner, you are no doubt aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest, in the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal 25 and we ask you to go beyond a simple proposal.
