communications that do not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all stakeholders of public services, and that do not meet the objectives that you otherwise set.
The European Union must convey a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To do this, we need to create a positive legal framework, regulation or directive.
The Lisbon Treaty provides us with the legal basis for this.
it is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now
I believe that Parliament is ready to follow you down this path.
Thank you, Mr. President. Well, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their enormous work on this discharge. And I also welcome the Council's presence for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not just a matter of economics.

I am speaking about this today in this chamber on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, led by Mann, as a mere means of making savings.
I am also interested in the issue of Parliament's expenditure.
In this regard, I propose that we hold the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels. This would allow us to make better use of our Parliament headquarters in Strasbourg.
And since we want to save money, I propose other things. For example, eliminating the Friday per diems for our colleagues. Also, eliminating the per diems for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that journalists do not need to be given a per diem.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond budgetary control, even though I commend the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about the economy, I also want to see a moralization and a cleaning up of the compensation system for groups of sponsored visitors.

I don't find it very moral, and it gives a very bad image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, on the day of the visit, without any work, no control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, as I would like to point out, the allocated sum exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for groups to send a quote in advance to the visits department, for them to receive an advance payment from Parliament, into a bank account, and for the balance to be paid upon presentation of invoices that have actually been paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is a space that has continuously expanded in recent years and now includes 25 states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

This is the context in which the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration should be read.
Mutual trust between the Schengen states is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
It should therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled border checks.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly encouraged to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level rather than through intergovernmental cooperation.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all measures envisaged in the long term with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, in conclusion, to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years has only highlighted a shortcoming of the Schengen Agreement.
Just two more minutes, Madam President. In a few weeks, migrants from the countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant percentage of annual French immigration.
This achievement is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.

I hope that these proposals will be adopted quickly in order to guarantee the public better management of our Schengen area and to ensure the security of our common external borders in the process. Thank you.
The European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, it seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any criticism of the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the government as an indulgence that allows it to intensify the
repression. Such cruel repression that it is impossible to imagine for a moment that at the same time Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the organization.
While today the Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Deira, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, in contempt, rightly so, of the values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avoid such a disaster?

Mrs Mathieu, one and a half minutes. Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho who has done a jeweler's job on this report and God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen control of their borders and have succeeded.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now in a position to implement this Schengen acquis in terms of both technical and personnel requirements.
Moreover, while there are currently no obstacles preventing the enlargement of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly monitored, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because as you know, mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full compliance by these States with their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
I sincerely hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circles of the Schengen States.
and we will all measure in this chamber the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all the Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have worked to strip the new Eurovignette Directive proposal of its content and block this issue.

Today, however, thanks to the perseverance of our rapporteur, and I would like to pay tribute here to Sad El Khadraoui, thanks to his perseverance and that of the shadow rapporteurs, in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

So, while this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, it will allow for the first time the implementation of the polluter-pays principle and the internalization of external transport costs, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this Eurovignette to be more than just a tax, but to actually contribute to improving transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in modernizing transport modes.
Parliament has also managed to secure concrete developments in the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we can adopt the compromise proposed to us in second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that, along with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with the peasants and the countries that have rejoined the Eastern countries that are rejoining,
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a major step forward with this report.
It wasn't easy at first and we were more in a confrontation, but we reached a consensus and that's what's most important.
This consensus helps to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur Morciedes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for both equality, justice and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe this is important.
We have said very clearly and confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which is essential for the quality and biodiversity of the territories.
I believe it was also fundamental
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, and turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now we need to implement this. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
it's not an ideological issue.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
it will be necessary to respond to it clearly

Now, what we are waiting for is for us to actually enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate. Because beyond the texts and the grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are headed. And that is what we are waiting for, of course, now.
I would like to finish by letting out a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has led to a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
it was in the CAP budget,
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are 80 million European citizens who do not eat properly.

Thank you, Mr President. While the European Parliament can boast of some significant progress in terms of economic governance, I urge my colleagues to remain humble, because we are dancing on the edge of a precipice.
Let us be well aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained inaudible during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all kinds of events with resolutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, and simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the member states, and to European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I want, these six directives and regulations, we will certainly take the eurozone one step further.
more towards a discipline that we have so sorely missed, a step, I say, nothing more, that will demonstrate its usefulness in the future.
But one need only look at the heated discussions surrounding the reversed qualified majority to measure the distance we still have to travel. While it should be about rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left benches continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are antonyms.

Yes, states must also manage their budget like a good family man, but not by stimulating the economy through public spending. This is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks promise to be crucial, the task at hand today is to rebuild an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is very important for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may account for 25% of all commerce in Europe in 20 years, which is quite considerable.
these purchases will notably be cross-border
They will allow consumers to have a wider choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, it is also a very important opportunity to expand their market.

Among the main advances, I would like to mention just two: the withdrawal period is extended to 14 days, and all the information and the total price to be paid are summarized before the final key is pressed to place the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously across the political groups, because on such a subject, it was not polemics that we needed, but obviously electoral consensus.
and we got it.

Mathieu Deminut. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, ladies, Commissioner, I would like to begin by commending the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult issue that required a great deal of technical expertise, hard work, and knowledge of the subject matter.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we face, and technology is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
In fact, over the past few years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a "digital tsunami" is certainly expected to materialize in the coming years.
The SIS, VIS and RODEX are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is of course very delicate and Carlos Coelho had to face numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles and he has nevertheless managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all the parties concerned.
The creation of this agency for networks appears to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the member states.
No other existing institution or agency could take charge of the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems, it will offer better synergy between these databases and will also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate issues that arose in this matter was the location of the agency. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have put themselves forward as candidates to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, where it has been managing its operational and administrative aspects since 1995. As a result, it has full technical control over it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council in December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wanted to host the headquarters of this future agency.

I believe that the compromise reached is very good. A kind of distribution of tasks has taken place, I conclude, Madam President, by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg
The cost-effectiveness ratio is very balanced and this understanding solution in no way calls into question the centralized management of IT systems. Thank you, Madam President.
The horizontal social clause and Article 14 of the Lisbon Treaty provide binding guarantees for social rights, including the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Our social achievements must therefore be given the place they deserve in Community law, by recognising the specific nature of SGEIs in relation to competition rules, bearing in mind that these services have strong local roots and rely on social economy players.

Mr. De Rosa's report is an opportunity to reaffirm the simple yet powerful principles of equality, universality, and access to these collectively organized services, which are key factors in promoting well-being and social progress.
Commissioner, you said it is time to move on to the practicalities.
Yes, it is time to get down to business. So, in this debate, I propose that we actually support a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution tabled by the Greens.
Thank you, Mr. President. Debates on GMOs must necessarily be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientifically and legally.
Legally, a wide range of solid arguments were needed for Member States wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur did, however, widen the margin range for my flat B.
When it comes to health, it's a bit more about health.
what is based on science must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged EFSA's scientific assessments, which have always been positive towards GMOs, in contrast to national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, would it not first be necessary, Commissioner, simply to apply the existing legislation that aims to provide a great deal of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations from October 2008 remained unimplemented?
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzitil for the tremendous work he has accomplished.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate her for that.
This report outlines for us an agency with a multiplied means, more in line with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally gets the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and benefit from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.
New tasks are also assigned to them, such as organizing voluntary returns or processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of competence enables us to consider and address migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than confining ourselves to a mere mechanical border management.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal that takes a step forward towards a sound and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continuous. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Meyer, and my colleagues for their sometimes critical comments. However, this 2010 activity report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
Yet it is the Commission that has a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, who can attend our debates himself.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as extensive expertise due to her direct relationship with citizens.
In fact, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also appreciate the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: listening to the problems of its citizens and united in finding solutions and protecting them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of exerting influence remain limited, particularly with regard to the environmental risks of projects that are sometimes almost complete.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will also be conducting a mission on this topic in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always rush to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
Finally, I appeal to the citizens. Continue to contact us through petitions as your directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to remind everyone of its extreme urgency.
First, we note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more pressing today.

The lack of a definition and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting, with the crisis worsening, that the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned about eradicating poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of STF by 2015.
Today, we have ourselves come somewhat closer to our goal.

Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, really been put to good use by the member states to concretely address this widespread precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely doubt it and I deeply regret it.

Finally, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy for homelessness, because of course there is poverty and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerability.
A comprehensive, effective, ambitious, but tailored approach is needed, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their experiences, and their life disruptions.
It is a fundamental right, to say the least, from which many of the most vulnerable people are deprived.
Thank you, Madam President. As everyone has said, in recent years the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters. And the cities here would take up the entire time of the debate.
I will still mention the AZF explosion, the 10th anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A reinforced reaction at European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity between our populations.

And for several years now, the Union has been trying to make this pooling of our efforts operational. And it is now time to act together and not wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before we learn from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to everyone in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for preventing and coordinating disaster responses.
And I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and support these flagship programs that provide Europe with undeniable added value.
There, I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it. It will thus pave the way for European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to increase within the European Union.
More than 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is serious.
Today, 6 member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a decision from the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July about the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions. But when millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four.
The emergency is real.
If nothing is done by the end of the year, food banks will be missing out on more than 300 million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to fill this gap.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible governing minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid because this is, above all, a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We need to fundamentally change the way we produce food in order to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest, who are entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to access this vital aid.
I am particularly addressing the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
come to your senses. Does it take food riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, suddenly no one is available. The Parliament made a strong statement last time: human beings are more important than finance.
it is high time to reaffirm it
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our appeal in a constructive manner.
Six Member States hold in their hands the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
six member states that claim they are doing nothing more or less than legalism
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm calls made by associations that help the most deprived?

And do we, as Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, want a Europe where national egoisms dictate policies, paying little heed to the citizens of states in budgetary difficulty?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No. Let's maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not abandon those who, right now, in 2012, are counting on this aid during particularly difficult times of crisis. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and particularly in Belgium, in Lige, which will eventually result in hundreds of direct layoffs and put several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a Lige native, I share the astonishment and dismay of the 581 workers who have been laid off from their family.
but I am also thinking of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons given? Always the same. Poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, fierce competition with imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction in the automotive market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example of the Lige site, compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, and despite a difficult 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of 1,394,000,000 euros.
He paid 0 euros in taxes, resulting in a tax rate of 0%.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across several sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than an economic adjustment variable where human issues are of little importance,
it is no longer acceptable.
Commissioner, did you talk about the rules?
Is it not time for the Commission to develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocation, corporate codes of conduct, reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
And since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we want to support the competitiveness of companies and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we also need to adopt a legislative framework.
Europe needs to be strong to cope with relocation and restructuring, and to ensure that another form of capital, human capital, is fully taken into account.
Finally, in the case of the Lige site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the redundant workers. Thank you.

Madam President, my dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs that is affecting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that act...

without any social ethics, which carries out stock market layoffs and relocates to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies, disregarding social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last on the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, the workers affected by the negative effects of restructuring.

But we also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the interventions of the European Fisheries Fund and the industrial policy of the European Union, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also worked to ensure that the future EMFF regulation includes improvements so that the EMFF does not produce the same random, moral effects on multinational companies as it does today, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look separately at the issue of structural funds and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund without...
considering the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the co-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat...
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Ombudsman conducts investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with great success.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors, who all too often say that the European Union is nothing more than a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsense. Europe is genuinely working on itself, thanks to European mediators in particular.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire for criticism.
First, there are the numbers. 65% is the real figure, not 12% of the inquiries opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also stakeholders. Many companies come to us to express their lack of understanding of the Commission, of a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, regarding the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people understand it.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain European Commission services present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member's questions or who hide behind empty words almost as well as politicians and wonder about citizens pleading their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the Ombudsman are Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by these concerns.
behavior. Citizens were then negatively affected by their confrontation with the institutions, perhaps creating a sense of rebellion, incomprehension, and eventually perhaps Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against the institutions in general are heard. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's topic is framed.
So we, the EPP Group, supported the report by our colleague Mrs. Matt Larkin, a report in which we contributed significantly, and we obviously support the people who have been affected.

The main recommendation of this report is to promote greater professional mobility, simplify and improve the efficiency of procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer protection.
but it is in terms of the path to growth that the challenge of increasing professional mobility arises.
And, indeed, the Forum for a Single Market held in Krakow at the beginning of October did not make a mistake about this.

who pointed out that the Member States had to recognise the potential of the internal market for boosting growth and job creation and had to act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of October 23rd also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving growth, in its own words, "intelligent, sustainable" growth.
including the implementation of the 12 priority proposals in the Single Market Act, the 12 proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications.

And we can clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unleash the growth potential contained in the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, if we modernize it, if we improve the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also allow us to acquire, we hope, additional margins of growth.
This is why we, particularly the EPP, want to emphasize a practical recommendation: we support the introduction of a voluntary professional card.
Thank you, Madam President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.
It is important that each year, the European Parliament draws up a report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, insofar as
This Assembly plays a crucial role in strengthening the North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a significant year for the APP, which met twice, as mentioned by the predecessors, in Spain and the DRC, to discuss various topics.
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or on media freedom and independence and food security.
But in 2010, the PA also sent its first election observation mission of this legislative term.
I had the honour of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was a resounding success.

We were able to meet all the relevant political stakeholders, and thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, which is both ACP and European, we embodied a legitimacy different from that of European or African missions.
I invite the ACP Bureau to renew this experience, which provides an opportunity to put into practice the solidarity and privileged relations that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We need more than ever to fulfill the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must perpetuate and optimize European funds, particularly the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at a horizontal level and it is now time to act to enable the most deprived to escape their precarious situation.

And we must, as political leaders, at the European, national and local levels, take the necessary measures to ensure that they have access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, a first job with a minimum income, perhaps indexed according to the poverty threshold of each Member State, without discrimination.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will enable us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.
The Europe we want and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Levin, for her excellent work.

As the draftsperson of the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing at global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and enforcement by all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints, without accompanying measures, on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be supported in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
And that is why the Union will need to increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources that these countries could derive from the fishing industry.
Or, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and education policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes, when implementing its measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states.
A holistic approach is necessary to stem the tide of this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to say that, in large part, thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe. Therefore, the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy on the sea, oceans, and seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, it will not be enough to achieve this great challenge.
The fight against illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent at the European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly through international cooperation.
I would also like to point out that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Runion are regularly violated and plundered.
Since the report does not mention this, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to begin by paying tribute to the Polish presidency, which has demonstrated dynamism and a strong sense of purpose.
Next week at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make crucial decisions for the future of the eurozone, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the relaunch of growth.

That being said, we can clearly see that financial stability has become the top priority today, and that the pressures and tensions exerted from outside the eurozone countries, as well as within the eurozone, are ruining our credibility and undermining trust.
And to hope for the return of confidence, we must restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debt.
Financial stability has become the priority of priorities, it has become an ardent obligation for all.
Our democracies have all embarked on very courageous programs to clean up their public finances and reduce their debts. But financial stability is also a prerequisite for any return to growth.
But who says solidarity, who says financial stability, budgetary discipline, because these go hand in hand, of course, must also say solidarity.
We believe it is important to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to disempower our democratic institutions.

rather than thinking about resorting to a jurisdictional mechanism, I would suggest that, in the case of budgetary drift, we should consider mechanisms of control and sanctions carried out by democratic institutions.

To be completely honest, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs. And quite frankly, even though I belong to the same political party as him, I am not constantly, I would say, in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be completely honest once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Jupp to that effect.

I simply think that France's current position is to constantly reaffirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that safeguarding the euro means that the euro is the heart of our European construction.

This is about safeguarding this common project and safeguarding the European Union. And in this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about protecting the younger generations and preserving peace on our continent.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, tomorrow we will be voting for the third time on the new cooperation instrument.
development that provides accompanying measures in the banana sector for ACP countries that export bananas, following the reduction of their tariff preference, the BAM.

While I deeply regret that not all of Parliament's demands regarding the implementation of delegated acts have been incorporated into this instrument.

And the Commission also made a statement specifying the methodology used.

Furthermore, we have a Council statement on the next Multiannual Financial Framework specifying that the latter will duly take into account the delegated acts in the instruments of external aid after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, Parliament specifies, and this point seems crucial to me, that this is in no way a precedent.
I have just returned from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU PA was held. I believe I can tell you that our ACP friends are counting on us given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the disastrous consequences for our ACP partners if the ICD-BAM were rejected.
The situation for some farmers is dramatic. We can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I am therefore counting on you to support the text. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Our coordinator Thijs Bergman cannot be present this evening due to personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis on this issue.

The conciliation on this legislative package was long and tedious, and while the result on the human rights instruments and ICAI+ is satisfactory, we are far from achieving the desired outcome regarding the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate that had been given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on the same level as the Council on all programming decisions concerning the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
Because it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Lisbon Treaty that are in question here.
The choice of programming priorities is a highly political decision in which our Assembly must have a say.
By categorically refusing to recognize any supervisory power for Parliament and by resorting to shameful blackmail, the Council has once again demonstrated a reprehensible ideological retreat.
But the Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal under the banal instrument.
This is the only way we can show the Council and the Commission that Parliament wants more transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurdity would be that we would have to wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers that the Lisbon Treaty already provides for.
At the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that a defense policy is an eminently national policy.
It meets the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Sharing capabilities is nothing other than an amputation of sovereignty. The single market for military equipment is a vast joke. When some Member States, believing that their
Defense is guaranteed in Washington, which primarily equips itself with American materials, as Europe is unable, in this field as in so many others, to impose Community preference.
Regarding the common security challenges of the EU member states, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, without any intervention from Brussels.

And I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Mrs. Ashton would be tantamount to acknowledging that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have the legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accept that the Mercosur couple can impose a purely German Europe on 27 peoples, a mental aberration.

For 30 years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary austerity, to the point of rendering most of our military tools obsolete.

deficient or outdated, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, with everyone expecting the neighbor or the supposed American big brother to make the efforts that they themselves are no longer willing to make.
But you are on the wrong track.

Only by returning to independent and resolute national policies will we be able to individually equip ourselves with the necessary means, not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to meet common challenges.
a sum of weaknesses and shortcomings has never made a strength.

Thank you, Mr President. I wanted to express support for the French PPE Group's statement on the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance in the Economic Union and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Make no mistake.
This treaty represents an important step towards greater economic and fiscal integration, towards greater financial stability.
Let us say it again here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without the sanitisation of our public finances.
Of course, growth cannot be decreed. It is not a treaty that, on its own, can revive growth.
but a treaty, that is to say a set of rules and mutual commitments, can bring confidence and accountability.

And since the president of the Socialist group saw fit to introduce party politics into this chamber, and by alluding to the upcoming French presidential campaign, mentioning the Socialist candidate in this French presidential election, I wanted to retaliate.
