Renegotiate what and with whom?
These words are totally irresponsible.
they pay little heed to the French state's word, to the respect of the French state's commitments.

Madam Ashton, good morning. Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading up to the presidential and legislative elections.
The country's growth is negative.
In normal times, our contribution is around 50% of the country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budget support for the 9th and 10th EDF lines, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population is suffering and companies based in Madagascar are sometimes forced to contribute despite themselves.

While supporting your position, we would like you to use all your influence with the SADEC to resolve the legal and judicial imbroglio concerning the return of the former president as soon as possible, as this is one of the most sensitive aspects of implementing this roadmap.

I would like to hear your opinion on the matter and also inform you that the European Union-Madagascar friendship group that we have just created in the European Parliament is available to work with you and the Commission in the interests of the Malagasy people and in defense of the values of our Union.

Mr President, dear colleague, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr Iturguise, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiation process he had to undertake and for the patience he has shown.

We are finally getting to the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens to this chamber, to the Commission and the Council.
This is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Environmental petitions are in the majority, and waste is a major concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal problem.
We are consuming all the time.
We are only now realizing that what we don't consume, we throw away.
This awareness must absolutely be reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
but this report is also a wake-up call for the member states.
It is still worrying to see that the states seem not to be in control of the situation.
Only six Member States have transposed the Waste Framework Directive on time.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of landfill sites.
Finally, and most worryingly, organized crime seems to be doing whatever it wants.
A market worth 75 billion euros inevitably attracts covetous eyes.
States must send a strong signal
Sanctions against companies that leak public contracts to enrich themselves must be increased.
This report is a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its role and verify the proper implementation of the waste directives.
This dossier must be made visible but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification procedures that may last for years.
Let us listen to the petitioners' message and stop this waste more quickly.
Commissioner, rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr Nicholson for the courage he has shown in the face of the Council and the Commission.
But despite this, I fear that what we have arrived at will not allow for a balance between producers and manufacturers.
This agreement reminds me of that well-known illusion, the one children tell about a paradise where vegetarian lions would graze next to sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs. Fischer-Bowl has done everything to ideologically destroy milk quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors nevertheless recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Or, today, we are in an even more dramatic situation, and we can see what is happening in Denmark, where the most solid farms, with the increase in production, are all in a state of bankruptcy, with the price of land falling by 40%.
Do we want this for the European level?
I say no, we need control of production with the participation of the public authorities. Thank you.
Commissioner, the personal data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our European minimum protection standards, which we rely on, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data are processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify their personal data, as well as the right to file a legal complaint in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action must be taken to allow European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a potential legal conflict that could harm European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European programme for monitoring the financing of terrorism,
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven effective in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and, consequently, the protection of European citizens' personal data.
The European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits, which threaten the European economy. However, this has not prevented social exclusion or the increase in unemployment.
It is time, indeed it is now urgent, for the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy to become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States with a view to growth.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that the focus should be on many topics such as, among others, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, etc.

Or, as Commissioner Andor pointed out earlier, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment that are not being used.
we could almost make it a 23-23 strategy.
And that's not counting the 60 billion euros in unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on the concept of "flexi-security".
So let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more tailored, with social incentives that are more advantageous than those related to unemployment and active support for all socially responsible businesses.
We had poverty reduction targets to meet by 2020, but we already know they will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and adequate measures taken by the member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy put into taking strong economic governance measures also applies to ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Thank you, Madam President. Undoubtedly, the women's cause owes a great deal to Europe.
The principle of gender equality was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been continuously reaffirmed in numerous treaties since then.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has always been very proactive in promoting gender equality and the cause of women's advancement.
Little by little, progress has been made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, directives have been implemented.
Right here, within our Parliament, there has been an extremely active and vigilant Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality for many years.
a European Institute for Gender Equality was established
Programs are being implemented, and financial resources are being allocated year after year.
And more recently, on 2 March, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of the European Day of Equal Treatment, Equal Pay, Equal Payers.
A European equal pay day. Undoubtedly, the legislative arsenal exists. The European will has been made concrete on several occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains relevant today, the struggle for gender equality and particularly for equal pay.
On average, there is always a wage gap of around 17% across all European Union countries.
For equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Commission of the Parliament is currently working on a draft resolution to call on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on equality of...
which is one of the most worrying issues and at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, the introduction of quotas, both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life. I come from a country, France, which adopted this long ago, more than
enacting binding quota rules in political life and, more recently, about a year ago, a law to establish quotas on the boards of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So, what is the outcome? After a few years of implementation in one case, a few months in another, it is clear that things have moved forward.
So, a necessary evil.
quotas have an effect.

Commissioner, you recently took an important step towards establishing European-level quotas in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this major public consultation to gather opinions on the actions to be implemented, including potential legislative measures.
On this matter, you will have my full and complete support. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics. Firstly, the issue of water management in the world and in Europe.
and then a question to the European Commission so that measures can be taken to address a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.
The issue, as we know, is that water is the major concern of the 21st century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
we know the stakes in terms of management, in terms of food safety,
And on the occasion of this forum, as our colleague Rivasi pointed out, too many purely commercial concerns are at the heart of the discussion that has taken place in Marseille in recent days.
A question, why is there no coherence between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy?
Nothing in the CAP reform indicates anything about this management, as our colleague Sarbou mentioned earlier.
So give us answers.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by thanking the rapporteur and our assistants for the work they have done.
This report now truly lives up to its name, which is to remove obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a wonderful project, but it is all too often noted that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Take the economic crisis, for example.
It has exposed our weaknesses and enabled us to build our single market regulatory institutions more robustly.
For the European citizen, it's the same.
The Committee on Petitions, a veritable complaints office, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European citizens' initiative will complete this framework.
Despite all our policies that call for mobility, adherence to European values, and exchanges, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
And a citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not vote. It is a citizen who will not see the benefits that Europe represents in their daily life.
Together with my fellow MEPs from the EPP, we have made a huge number of proposals, the most numerous, and I would like to thank them for that.
This is a report that should produce a sense of belonging and European identity that we need to recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has made 25 very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are essential for restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens. Online shopping, moving house, children's rights, employment, prevention.
citizen participation, healthcare abroad, twinning, minority rights, etc. We still struggle too much to fully benefit from the opportunities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are the relays for this.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must demonstrate to citizens that, alongside free movement, there is also free exercise of rights in Europe.
I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviors.

I believe that energy consumption must be aligned with an indicative price signal for the consumer, and above all, I think that in order to avoid any distortion in the internal market, we must try to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportionality in the different levels of taxation on energy products therefore seems to me to be a necessity.
And in this case, for example, it would put an end to the current diesel tourism, which is not acceptable.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposed directive revision.

Nevertheless, if we are to achieve our goals in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or improving energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not penalize citizens or sectors that are particularly vulnerable to the transition.

global market prices, and I am thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, albeit differentiated according to the level of taxation in each Member State, but nonetheless an impact on the price of diesel.
The question is who, in the end, will have to bear this price increase?
Are there any real alternatives that are practical, realistic, and accessible to consumers?
As the shadow rapporteur for the environment committee, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable position for everyone.

I therefore advocate for greater progressivity and for the proposal and its principle of proportionality to come into effect in 2030, subject to a new impact study, updating the one on which the Commission is based and which was carried out five years ago.

Here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in 9 European member states, which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to a demand for steel in Berne.
Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg, and the temporary closure of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6,000 direct jobs will be at risk in 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop and go, a practice that should be better regulated, there is the broader issue of European steel production and adaptation to change, which requires extremely urgent answers.

Six months ago, the Commission announced to us the need to conduct a new consultation exercise in light of the economic crisis, for responsible management of restructuring with the social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple, 6 months later, where are we?
Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to begin by debunking the unfounded allegations that 500,000 to 1 million fake biometric passports are circulating in France.
France takes the risk of identity document fraud very seriously
She does not take offences in this matter lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a 15,000 euro fine.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, allowing prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, a fraud liaison officer is appointed in each prefecture.
In addition, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data provided can be verified between administrative departments, as much as possible by dematerialized means, in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same strictness applies to proof of address documents.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards increased security of proof of address with the insertion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title application includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title applications, and possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the issuance of documents is further guaranteed by the applicant's dual appearance 1 at the time of application submission and subsequently at the time of document collection, as well as the collection of two fingerprints.
And that's not to mention the enhanced checks for renewing lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, particularly Interpol, I am finishing, Mr. President, I am almost done, about passports that have been issued, lost, or stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed to

Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, let's establish a fact: our fellow citizens increasingly wish to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food, particularly for health and quality reasons.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining nearby slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous health control, enable the development of local short supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable peasants to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

Direct sales on the farm should be encouraged and facilitated, and collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points should be supported, allowing a wider range of products to be offered to local consumers.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery systems such as AMAP in France, which enable nearly 3,000 farmers to supply 60,000 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product, in order to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, and my dear colleagues. I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the funding of ITER, which was voted on by a large majority in the Committee on Budgets on 29 March, has been adopted.
By financing this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic fundamental research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
It should be noted that none of the seven partners in the Euratom community have questioned their overall contribution to the project.
Despite the Fukushima disaster, Japan has decided to scrupulously respect its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people are working for ITER on a day-to-day basis.
From 2015 to 2017-2018, the construction phase of the buildings and assembly of the machine could employ up to 4,000-5,000 people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major environmental challenges facing us in 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh environmental action programme by creating synergies between existing financial frameworks and mobilising new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and coordination between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is battering the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate field.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially when it comes to the effective use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco-design, recycling, and the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental education that is necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a political programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.
It must provide the necessary readability and predictability to national and local governments, citizens, as well as entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the profound changes that our world is undergoing today, the EU must reform its generalised system of preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not break the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from perfect. We must bear in mind that this regulation is aimed at developing countries.
In developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its efforts on the poorest countries,
This does not seem entirely sustainable at first glance,
To achieve this, the Commission has nevertheless developed a strictly accounting approach, based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
The limitations of this approach are clear.
What about the many middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies that are vulnerable to climate risks?
The compromise reached with the Council does not address this issue, which is why I am calling on my fellow Members to vote in favour of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the various plans of the European Union is unfortunately not new.
This is a crucial issue in my opinion. To this end, I have not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally written to Mr Barroso.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as the Court of First Instance of the European Communities recalled in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, according to which public consultations do not claim to provide a completely representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
That's not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria that would allow us to measure an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented because of the sole availability in English, for example, they miss their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to retain written consultations as a tool at the basis of the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must ensure democratic, transparent, and fair security for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission opts for written consultation, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle

The analysis should also take into account the excessively short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which unfortunately are mainly accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and failing states will be imposed by the technocrats in Brussels, budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced monitoring is called guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, and caned, one might say that financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent budget austerity alone by means of growth measures, your proposals are only there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian European state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Thank you, Mr. President. Without disregarding the importance of the economic choices we must assume, may I insist on a remark of a more political nature in the context of this debate?
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain major European leaders, or those who believe themselves to be such.
While everyone continues to advocate for a coordination of economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that is finally worthy of the name, and while this demand even appears to be a genuine condition,
sine qua non for the survival of the eurozone, once settled in their own countries, these gentlemen believe they are being clever by denigrating the balanced recommendations coming from
the Commission to be freed from certain commitments or, in the worst case scenario, to turn public opinion against these "Brussels edicts", as they are called.
This irresponsible attitude would be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
Let me be perfectly clear: our debates on stability, the necessary streamlining of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed geared towards the economy.
if the past mistakes regarding debt and public deficit do not come to an end and if the governments of the Member States continue in their misfortune.
We are playing with fire right now.
European discipline must apply to everyone, without exception, even to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg,
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinion is ready for it, much more so than some of their leaders would like to believe.
And one last word to Madame Goulard, otherwise I have to show her the blue card. I would say in conclusion to Madame Goulard, in Redemption, there is Racha.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to begin by commending the determination of the European Commission, and particularly yours, Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the relaunch and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you pointed out, Commissioner, for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors that require more of an internal market. More internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually made it clear that it attached great importance to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
And rather than constantly trying to invent new growth instruments, we would be better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to a vote by our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States: more speed and efficiency in the transposition of the directives that have already been agreed upon.
More mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects. I will mention just one, that of strengthening worker mobility. More ease of movement, more fluidity of movement.
Commissioner, we will be eagerly awaiting the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political will and the ability to put pressure on the member states. Thank you.
We experienced the Mediator scandal a while ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the shortcomings in European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, this 14-year fraud from 1996-2010, went unpunished,
There are 500,000 prostheses worn worldwide, 8,000 implant recalls, and 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
There have finally been 3,500 complaints filed. This figure is frightening, shocking.

How, despite the warnings from the American drug agency, FDA, Commissioner, and the number of complaints and convictions for breast implant ruptures filed in Great Britain, particularly in France, how could national and European agencies have missed such a scam?
This tragedy immediately prompted us to think about improving the European system for monitoring medical devices, as you just explained.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today that can prevent scandal. But it is a new system that needs to be built.
This new legislation is expected to be announced in the autumn, as you mentioned.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied with it.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as set out in this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not want to create a marketing authorization for class 3 medical devices, which are the most at risk?
Commissioner Dali, can you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than 2.5%. At the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England, and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production, and we need to organize the volumes of production and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today, producers are suffering from an increase of more than 44% in the price of plant proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that the added value is shared between producers and that farmers are not the victims of companies and large-scale distribution.

So I am asking the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the undermining of control over production. But at the same time, I am saying very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own back yards, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
And that is also why these quotas have been called into question.
So there is a dual responsibility, that of the Commission and that of the Member States.
Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European rail area: what a fine example of European integration policy.
This is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized for being stuck in a rut, Europe is finally showing the way with this directive, setting the course for a major sustainable transport policy and opening up a vast field for rail investment policy for employment.

I welcome the main measures taken in the organization of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, and the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract, thus stipulating the organization's funding commitments.

railway infrastructure, but I am also pleased about the establishment of transparency in financial flows between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder about non-discriminatory access to certain

And finally, I welcome the confirmation by European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, particularly on a social level. For example, the absence of a reference to minimum service, as well as to full unbundling between the GECNR and the operator.

but allow me to mention a requirement that is no longer being considered, particularly by the European Commission: the liberalization of the railway sector as the only strategic goal for the development of a single railway area, and thus decide on a European integrated investment strategy that is favorable to employment in Europe.
So, to conclude, I would like to ask you a question, Mr. Commissioner Callas.
Three days after the European Council of June 28 and 29, following the approval of a 120 billion growth pact to stimulate the European economy,
notably through investment in infrastructure. Could you tell us, Commissioner, how much funding the European rail sector is likely to receive under this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address an issue this evening that is certainly peripheral, but extremely important in this context.

I tell you, if you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these remarks seem to me to be a misunderstanding of the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, democracy in general, and the citizens we represent.
At a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President.
Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you most sincerely.
Thanks to your persistence and procedural tricks, you are allowing us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and 2.8 million to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that the elected European officials are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you once again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I salute them. It's a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are all too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
this is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like to thank you tomorrow for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Pongard, draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to point out that when the European Union wishes to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

In fact, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial in my view that measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies put in place by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore call on the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to take due account of the level of development and vulnerability of the countries concerned. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as claimed by environmental organizations and the European Commission, which lump all categories of fishing together.

It goes without saying that fish stocks must be preserved, but our fishermen must also be able to make a living from their activity, and the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions must be preserved.
Or the main measures of the European executive once again aim to reduce the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the implementation of individual transferable quotas, a guarantee of the industrialization and concentration of the sector, as well as a total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but as it stands, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner. I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, for this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the field of energy between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in trilogue will allow for the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and for pragmatic reasons, one can only be pleased about this.
Energy Europe is making progress, certainly not fast enough, but it is making progress.
As a major energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate information on energy agreements more widely to the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus make it possible to anticipate energy supply problems.
I am pleased that this decision does not create any obligation regarding agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes in terms of competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to protect the interests of our companies and the rules protecting private contracts.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this issue.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very long way off with the Commission's basic proposal. There was no specific mention of the outermost regions, which are directly affected by competition from Latin American countries. There was no automatic trigger.

under the stabilisation mechanism, there is no possibility for our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, and social and environmental standards are not taken into account as potentially constituting a competitive and fair advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the Committee on International Trade.
However, this is not enough, because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions that already have record unemployment rates.
Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by thanking Charles Gorenz for his excellent report.
We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline approaches in 2015, even though some goals seem
Having achieved this, we must ask ourselves how we can improve our aid, making it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, and land grabbing force us to define new priorities. Priority to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, there is a European consensus, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that function well in terms of decision-making, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally and most importantly, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not just about charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were still developing countries not long ago.
As major economic powers, these countries must now also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than just a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Thank you, Mr. President. The agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wants the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid to be based, from 2014 onwards, on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per inhabitant.
Or, as Mrs Ashton pointed out, these issues are not just accounting matters, but deserve a genuine political debate on the definition of our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Moreover, in my opinion, this differentiated approach is not in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us salute the initiative taken by Jacques Delors 20 years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall was falling.
And yet, despite all the progress we have seen since the beginning of our debate, it must be acknowledged that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
So I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we will build together a fairer Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

And there are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues, which are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it, tax harmonization, public services,
protector, minimum wage in Europe, establishment of enhanced cooperation, job creators, facilitating cross-border cooperation and developing a fair trade policy.
These are the challenges, I believe, that lie ahead of us 20 years later.
And I am counting on you, Commissioner, to work together with me to promote this fine policy of European construction.

Thank you, Mr President. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have taken a close interest in my colleague Regina Bastos's report on the 20 main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We have discussed this report in connection with our debate on the 20th anniversary of the internal market.
It has already been 20 years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully implemented within our living space, exchange space, and internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that the primary concern expressed by our European citizens is the licensing of professional qualifications, and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens expect in order to truly establish in the very near future procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are truly faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP group on this subject, the modernisation of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to truly meet this major mobility challenge.
More mobility for more Europe. That is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
This year, the Committee on Petitions gained the right to be automatically associated with the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
For me, this is the most significant signal of 2011 for this committee.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in case of violation of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can thus be increasingly seen as the preferred interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also found in the results of the Committee on Petitions' positions.
All too often, we are approached by citizens who are facing legal entanglements on which we would like to take a stand. But while the problems are European,
the solutions should be European, but we remain powerless because subsidiarity is still not compatible with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties faced by many parents with children born of binational unions, we in Parliament remain powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, especially from Germany which sends a large number of petitions, following the model of the Dfenseur des Droits in France, has not been acted upon.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a solution that reconciles the European problem with the national solution.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet citizens' expectations
The 2013 European Year of Citizenship will have to address citizens' grievances and the costs of the forces, but we need the means to act in order to be effective.
